message: I'd recommend that you make it as an aggregator for various sources that already do this (such as the GitHub profile pages).
I'm thinking of setting up some kind of a profile where I say which of my projects I'm developing and maintaining, and which I still want to develop but currently am not
can anyone link to a good example of this?
I do this as an 'archive' http://kennethreitz.com/projects/archive/
@bat thanks :) which one?
and i use this for the main page: http://kennethreitz.com/projects/
Ahh, I tried that for a little while in like 07
Think I was using pmwiki at the time
http://dpaste.de/4TwJ/ -- @kennethreitz know anything that fits that profile?
hmm. yeah, the github page does a good job of showing what's happened recently
i google that word and the only thing that comes up is your github profile :)
nice bullet-point manifesto. I agree with you on most of them.
i have a few
that's the one
haha, thank you
I'm toying around with switching to a statically generated site
but i'll likely never actually do it
That's effectively what I'm hoping to get out of a static site generator. Basically a pretty web wrapper for git-as-a-content-store
which pulls all the data from the api
...if not all...
supports / opposes ?
bliks (blog+wiki) with the ability to set different layouts for different pages & sets of pages
do you support blikizines?
WordPress is the way to go
I've been meaning to do this, but have the final product be some couchdb docs: http://paulstamatiou.com/how-to-wordpress-to-jekyll
json docs for couchdb, that is
WP is a formidable foe :)
and then host it at couchone or cloudant
Or rather, to be closer to that ideal than we are today
@bat I would suggest outlining what it is that would exactly entail, and what it would take to get there, then ask people if it exists in hollow hopes that they will build it for you.
@justinlilly what I want is a (set of) libraries for building a custom cms

I think a good start would be json implementations of various unix tools, like diff, patch, cat (combining), sed, and if you imagine a json document as a filesystem, ls, tree, and the ability to refer to paths.
@kennethreitz I want a web app that can help me realize more specifically what I support/oppose
I've played with Pelican, which was really awesome
Seems like a great starting poing
@justinlilly that looks awesome
*point
easily extensible
http://blog.notmyidea.org/pelican-a-simple-static-blog-generator-in-python.html

@justinlilly Thanks. I got some bites when I prototyped but no partner for the project. I didn't fully realize that more people interested means more of a chance finding someone to work on it with me.
Hypothetically, what would you add to both the GitHub project and user pages?
@pengwynn: 'featured projects'
so needed
I think featured projects make a lot of sense. I make more changes to my emacs and bash files than anything, but no one cares about that. I'd rather highlight my other things.
@pengwynn Project page is the repo detail page?
@kennethreitz Pelican is AGPL :(
@justinlilly that sucks, but luckily i'm not making a product out of it ;)
That, right there, though is enough of a reason to come up with a new system though.
